Objective

Cram and Juvavum are two-person games. You take turns against the computer. In each move, you put dominoes on the board. The game ends when no more dominoes can be placed. The objective of the game is to make the last move.

Rules of Domino Juvavum

A domino occupies two (horizontally or vertically) neighbouring fields. In each move, you can place as many dominoes on the board as you wish but they all have to be either in the same row or in the same column.

Rules of Cram

The rules of Cram are the same except that you are only allowed to place a single domino in each move.

Variation: Misère form

Both games can be played in their normal form or in what is called misère form. In the latter, the player making the last move loses.

Make a move

Tap on the fields you want to occupy. You can use swipe gestures to fill multiple fields.

You can modify your move by tapping on a filled field again.

You can undo your current move by double-tapping outside of the board.

Once you are happy with your move, tap the "Confirm move" button below the board.

Colours

Your dominoes will be displayed in red. The computer\'s will be shown in blue.

Start a new game

Tap "New game" above the board.

Change the game settings

Choose "Settings" from the menu.

If you make changes to the game settings a new game will be started automatically once you return to the board.

If you choose a non-quadratic board (for example, 3 x 7) it will be rotated to best fit the screen. For example, a 3 x 7 board will be rendered as a 7 x 3 board in portrait mode.

History

The game Cram was popularized by Martin Gardner in 1974.

Domino Juvavum was introduced by Peter Gerl at the University of Salzburg. Juvavum (or Iuvavum) was the name of the Roman settlement which developed into today\'s city of Salzburg, Austria.
